docs.lead_paragraph: THE revolutionary discovery of a hormone made by the human heart is scarcely two years old, but it has already spawned a whole new field of reseach as scientists begin to understand the substance's natural role and investigate ways of using it to treat heart disease, high blood pressure and kidney failure. Specialists who study heart and kidney function are fascinated by what they have already learned about the hormone. It helps dispose of excess sodium in the blood and thus seems to play a role in regulating the amount of salt in the body. It appears to act as a counterbalance to other vital hormones in governing blood volume and pressure. It is present in large amounts in the blood of patients who suffer from congestive heart failure and certain kinds of abnormally fast, irregular heartbeats. In animal experiments even small amounts of the hormone gave powerful aid to the functioning of failing kidneys.

headline.main: WIDE EFFECTS OF HEART HORMONE ARE FOUND

docs.lead_paragraph: Addressing an anti-crack rally in Washington Square Park yesterday, Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern told about 150 Greenwich Village residents that the park would close this week for renovations as part of an effort to rid it of drug dealers. Mr. Stern said the park would be closed from Wednesday to Saturday morning for the $100,000 project. In addition to the renovations, which are to include a thorough cleaning of the 8.6-acre park and the repair of benches, Mr. Stern said the park's current 1 A.M. curfew would be changed to midnight and would be enforced more strictly.

headline.main: FEAR OF DRUGS PROMPTS PARK RENEWAL

docs.lead_paragraph: Sex and School Clinics The Board of Education will consider the distribution of contraceptives at school health clinics. Robert F. Wagner Jr., the board's president, is expected to ask the board members to endorse such a program. He will also urge sex education throughout the system. At a public meeting afterward, look for family planning groups and religious organizations to vent their differences. Public session after 6 P.M. meeting, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn Interstate Homeless Newark Mayor Sharpe James, who last month set a time limit for New York City to remove its homeless from a New Jersey motel, will announce whether he intends to enforce today's deadline. Mayor Koch said yesterday that it would be ''cruel'' to evict the 44 families but that he would not contest the order if it came. 11 A.M., City Hall, 920 Broad Street, Newark
